verses.text: Jesus left the temple and was going away, when his disciples came to him to point out the buildings of the temple.
verses.comment: Jesus leaving the temple signals the coming end of Old Covenant worship centered at the temple (see also Ezek. 10:18). Recognizing the significance of the physical temple foreshadows the transition to God's dwelling among His people through Christ (see John 2:19-21).

verses.text: But he answered them, 'Do you see all these things? Truly, I say to you, not one stone will be left here upon another that will not be thrown down.'
verses.comment: Jesus prophesies the destruction of the temple, which was fulfilled in AD 70. This shows his divine authority and foreknowledge. This prophecy connects to Daniel 9:26 and foreshadows a new center for worship, built not of stones but spiritually (see 1 Pet. 2:4-5).

verses.text: As he sat on the Mount of Olives, the disciples came to him privately, saying, 'Tell us, when will these things be, and what will be the sign of your coming and of the end of the age?'
verses.comment: The Mount of Olives is where prophecy and fulfillment meet (see Zech. 14:4). The disciples associate the temple's destruction with the final coming of the Messiah, showing Jewish expectations. Jesus will answer with both near and far fulfillments.

verses.text: And Jesus answered them, 'See that no one leads you astray.'
verses.comment: The warning against deception is foundational for the disciples: spiritual vigilance is required in every age. Authentic teaching is to be valued, keeping to the apostolic faith (see Gal. 1:8-9).

verses.text: For many will come in my name, saying, 'I am the Christ,' and they will lead many astray.
verses.comment: Jesus predicts false messiahs will arise, a repeated warning throughout the New Testament. Cling to the faith delivered once for all to the saints (Jude 3).

verses.text: And you will hear of wars and rumors of wars. See that you are not alarmed, for these things must happen, but the end is not yet.
verses.comment: Jesus teaches that turmoil in the world does not mean the end has come; faith must not waver during earthly upheavals.

verses.text: For nation will rise against nation, and kingdom against kingdom, and there will be famines and earthquakes in various places.
verses.comment: Jesus continues to lay out the trials of the age. These are birth pains (v. 8), suggesting that suffering precedes new life — as in the story of redemption.

verses.text: All these are only the beginning of birth pains.
verses.comment: The image of birth pains is significant: suffering in this world is not the end, but the beginning of God's greater work. The Church experiences these pains as it moves toward final fulfillment.

verses.text: Then they will hand you over to be persecuted, and will kill you, and you will be hated by all nations because of my name.
verses.comment: Those living the faith are called to bear witness, even suffering for Christ. Persecution is a mark of true discipleship (see 2 Tim. 3:12).

verses.text: And then many will fall away and betray one another and hate one another.
verses.comment: The apostasy Jesus describes emphasizes the need for perseverance and the unity of the faithful.

verses.text: And many false prophets will rise and will deceive many.
verses.comment: The danger of false teaching is always present; Christ’s people must discern the true doctrine and listen to the appointed teachers.

verses.text: And because lawlessness will increase, the love of many will grow cold.
verses.comment: Spiritual coldness results from lawlessness and separation from the fullness of truth and grace.

verses.text: But the one who endures to the end will be saved.
verses.comment: Endurance is necessary for salvation—salvation is both a gift and a call to perseverance and faithfulness.

verses.text: And this gospel of the kingdom will be proclaimed throughout the whole world as a testimony to all nations, and then the end will come.
verses.comment: The true gospel is universal, offered to all nations. The worldwide mission of the Church is prefigured here, pointing to the unity and universality of the faith.

verses.text: So when you see the abomination of desolation spoken of by the prophet Daniel, standing in the holy place (let the reader understand),
verses.comment: A specific reference to Daniel’s prophecy, implying both a past historical and future spiritual fulfillment—interpreted as both the destruction of Jerusalem and any great profanation of the sacred.

verses.text: Then let those who are in Judea flee to the mountains.
verses.comment: Jesus gives practical and urgent direction, which was literally fulfilled in the flight of Christians to Pella before Jerusalem's fall.

verses.text: Let the one who is on the housetop not go down to take what is in his house,
verses.comment: The speed and urgency in leaving highlight the severity of coming judgment.

verses.text: And let the one who is in the field not turn back to get his cloak.
verses.comment: Again, immediate action is critical. The call is to trust God’s providential care, even over earthly concerns.

verses.text: And woe to those who are pregnant and to those who are nursing babies in those days!
verses.comment: A lament for the vulnerable underscores the real suffering accompanying these judgments; shows Jesus’ compassion.

verses.text: Pray that your flight may not be in winter or on a Sabbath.
verses.comment: Winter weather or Sabbath restrictions would hinder escape, showing God's care even in warnings and His respect for sacred times.

verses.text: For then there will be great tribulation, such as has not been from the beginning of the world until now, and never shall be.
verses.comment: The ‘great tribulation’ has both historical and future dimensions, prefiguring anti-Christian persecutions and the ultimate trial before Christ’s return.

verses.text: And if those days had not been cut short, no flesh would be saved. But for the sake of the elect, those days will be cut short.
verses.comment: God’s providence preserves the faithful, often called the 'elect.' Preservation depends not on human striving but on divine mercy.

verses.text: Then if anyone says to you, 'Look, here is the Christ!' or 'There he is!' do not believe it.
verses.comment: Jesus warns of false messiahs; the true return of Christ will be unmistakable and not localized.

verses.text: For false christs and false prophets will arise and perform great signs and wonders, so as to deceive, if possible, even the elect.
verses.comment: Supernatural signs are not enough to validate a message. The faithful are called to discernment, and trust in the guides God has provided for the maintenance of truth.

verses.text: See, I have told you beforehand.
verses.comment: Jesus's forewarning is intended to give spiritual confidence. Prophecy is a sign of his authority.

verses.text: So, if they say to you, 'Look, he is in the wilderness,' do not go out. If they say, 'Look, he is in the inner rooms,' do not believe it.
verses.comment: The Messiah’s return will not be secretive. This guards against trusting in any so-called messiah outside the tradition handed down by the apostles.

verses.text: For as the lightning comes from the east and shines as far as the west, so will be the coming of the Son of Man.
verses.comment: The second coming will be instant, visible, and glorious. Jesus uses a title from Daniel 7, which has strong claims to divinity and messianic authority.

verses.text: Wherever the corpse is, there the vultures will gather.
verses.comment: A proverb indicating that judgment will be obvious; evil will bring about its own exposure and ruin.

verses.text: Immediately after the tribulation of those days, the sun will be darkened, and the moon will not give its light, and the stars will fall from heaven, and the powers of the heavens will be shaken.
verses.comment: Cosmic signs are associated with the Day of the Lord. This language points both to the end of an age (as at Jerusalem’s fall) and the final end of history.

verses.text: Then will appear in heaven the sign of the Son of Man, and then all the tribes of the earth will mourn, and they will see the Son of Man coming on the clouds of heaven with power and great glory.
verses.comment: This verse is a high claim: Jesus is the heavenly Son of Man who comes as judge. The sign in heaven is traditionally understood as a visible manifestation, sometimes interpreted as the cross. Jesus’ return will be undeniably glorious.

verses.text: And he will send out his angels with a loud trumpet call, and they will gather his chosen from the four winds, from one end of heaven to the other.
verses.comment: The gathering of the chosen points to the final union of the faithful in glory. Christ’s authority is absolute—angels do His bidding.

verses.text: From the fig tree learn this parable: as soon as its branch becomes tender and puts out its leaves, you know that summer is near.
verses.comment: The faithful are called to discern the times, as leaves show the changing of the season.

verses.text: So also, when you see all these things, you know that he is near, at the very gates.
verses.comment: Awareness and vigilance characterize the lives of those awaiting Christ’s coming.

verses.text: Truly, I say to you, this generation will not pass away until all these things have taken place.
verses.comment: ‘This generation’ is understood by many as the people then alive; some see it as referring to the continuing people of God. Some elements were fulfilled in AD 70, some remain to be fulfilled.

verses.text: Heaven and earth will pass away, but my words will not pass away.
verses.comment: Jesus claims an everlasting authority for his words, a powerful statement of his divinity.

verses.text: But concerning that day and hour no one knows, not even the angels of heaven, nor the Son, but the Father only.
verses.comment: The mystery of God’s timing is hidden. Jesus, in his incarnate mission, humbly refrains from self-assertion; this reflects his perfect obedience to the Father, a model for all Christians.

verses.text: For as were the days of Noah, so will be the coming of the Son of Man.
verses.comment: The sudden judgment of the flood prefigures Christ’s return: the faithful are to watch and be ready.

verses.text: For as in those days before the flood they were eating and drinking, marrying and giving in marriage, until the day when Noah entered the ark,
verses.comment: Ordinary life continues until the moment of judgment; a warning to always be spiritually prepared.

verses.text: And they did not know until the flood came and swept them all away—so also will be the coming of the Son of Man.
verses.comment: Many will be taken by surprise at Christ’s return; the Church must call everyone to readiness.

verses.text: Then two men will be in the field; one will be taken and one left.
verses.comment: This imagery points to a final, sudden separation based on readiness—interpreted by many in light of final judgment, not a secret event.

verses.text: Two women will be grinding at the mill; one will be taken and one left.
verses.comment: Ordinary life continues, but divine judgment suddenly divides people—even among the ordinary and unnoticed.

verses.text: Therefore, stay awake, for you do not know on what day your Lord is coming.
verses.comment: Spiritual vigilance is commanded—expectancy and faithfulness are central to the Christian life.

verses.text: But understand this: if the master of the house had known in what part of the night the thief was coming, he would have stayed awake and would not have let his house be broken into.
verses.comment: The Lord’s coming will be sudden—disciples must always be prepared, never presuming upon their own security.

verses.text: Therefore you also must be ready, for the Son of Man is coming at an hour you do not expect.
verses.comment: Readiness points to a life lived in faith, hope, and charity, always oriented to Christ’s return.

verses.text: Who then is the faithful and wise servant, whom his master has set over his household, to give them their food at the proper time?
verses.comment: The faithful servant gives to the household at the proper time—interpreted spiritually as the shepherds of the people, who feed the faithful with teaching and sacramental life.

verses.text: Blessed is that servant whom his master will find so doing when he comes.
verses.comment: Blessing comes to those found faithfully fulfilling their vocation in the Church.

verses.text: Truly, I say to you, he will set him over all his possessions.
verses.comment: Faithfulness in the present life is rewarded with greater responsibility in the kingdom to come.

verses.text: But if that wicked servant says to himself, 'My master is delayed,'
verses.comment: Impatience and presumption lead to wickedness—end-time delay is no excuse for faithlessness.

verses.text: and begins to beat his fellow servants and eats and drinks with drunkards,
verses.comment: Abuses of authority and lack of charity are condemned; the Church is to be marked by loving service.

verses.text: the master of that servant will come on a day when he does not expect him and at an hour he does not know,
verses.comment: Unfaithful servants face judgment—readiness and right conduct are needed at all times.

verses.text: and will cut him in pieces and put him with the hypocrites. In that place there will be weeping and gnashing of teeth.
verses.comment: Final judgment is severe for those who neglect their calling. The repeated mention of ‘weeping and gnashing of teeth’ refers to real consequences—discipline and mercy are both central themes in the life of faith.
